text: the 17 Jan is the spicy one so far this is where people are positioning and again I continue to highlight things as I see them which is important in that this is relatively new for GameStop typically speaking we see so much of the total open interest in the front expirations this has been about a month now that we've continually seen oi a little further out in time now it was up to 60 days out when I first started noticing it now obviously the 17 Gen is about 35 days to expiration but that's where most of this is which is again really interesting just because it's slightly different one of the things that you'll notice when we do any sort of options analysis or stock analysis for that perspective is you have to build a baseline understanding of what you're looking at what is normal is entirely relative to the stock that you're looking at so for example GameStop it's pretty normal at this point to have call oi exceed put oi if we take a look at something else by comparison like spy you'll notice it's the inverse you almost always will see put oi exceed call oi so you have to understand the individual ticker that you're looking at because there's unique qualities this to me is noteworthy not because calls exceed puts again that's generally the standard here but it's that the ratio between these that's now what I track for GameStop because

text: because I do think as we start to see GameStop have stronger earnings as it continues to evolve I absolutely expect to see things like post earnings announcement drift exist in something like this and for those that are unfamiliar I have a couple videos that talk about post earnings announcement Drift But post earnings announcement drift it tends to happen when you have a company that has a big earnings beat so if you take a look here the earnings was 95 cents it came in at a125 that's a big beat and then it's typically followed if it's going to exhibit post earnings announcement drift to the positive side it's typically coupled with a gap right so it typically means that there's some sort of really new news that's led to repricing and re-evaluation of the value of a stock and that tends to carry out over time because it's not immediately priced in big big sources of money take some time to move around so that's post earnings announcement drift and I would not be surprised at all to see GameStops start exhibiting that once it starts having slightly stronger earnings but I think it's why even though they had a beat in this instance it didn't necessarily Drive uh poster his announcement drift one way or the other because of that so back to the options chain we have really light volatility I mean it's it's essentially sub 100 across all of it the front is

text: to us and the Discord is completely free to join but that's an important point now this does not surprise me at all and this is also a big reason why we continue to see the far out of the monies being populated both by my expectation being institutions and Retail Traders alike I don't think it's one or the other I think it's both of them and I think they both have their specific reasons for doing so now for the retail trading perspective it's typically a tough position to take on because retail Traders tend to have smaller Bank roles so then when they put on these positions that are very low hit rate that's the nature of this style trade this is the kind of trade that you put on a 100 times and you expect it to hit twice something like that now for a smaller retail Trader if you put this on 100 times and you miss 60 something in a row that can erode your bank roll depending on how you're sizing the trades for larger institutions they literally amortise out how many times they expect to hit on some sort of move that they can monetize to make sure that they're positively expected but the only way you can achieve that kind of risk-reward profile and positive expected return from this is to have a large enough bankroll and and to size appropriately which I think a lot of retail Traders unfortunately don't
